awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Focused Ion Beam-Scanning Electron Microscope for the Multidisciplinary Research and Education at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal aim of this project is to facilitate multidisciplinary research for three-dimensional reconstructions of highly complex microscopic samples that have not yet been achieved but are crucial for the interpretation of topology and geometry of surface and shape attributes of various types of specimens relating to energy materials, petroleum, geology, and biological systems. The project will significantly transform the study of the nano/microstructure and chemical composition of a wide variety of inorganic and organic compounds and provide scientific insights that would otherwise be unattainable, and will be integrated with other analytical tools. The project will also encompass significant educational and outreach activities, including collaboration with local schools and Science Museum, multi-year undergraduate and graduate research programs, advanced technical training and inclusive workforce development for future electron microscopists. 

Goals of this project are to (i) investigate the role of interface structures on the durability of high-performance fuel cell electrodes, (ii) enable an understanding of materials for solid-state batteries, (iii) unravel the unexpected catalytic activity in mesoporous oxides, (iv) explore the role of nano/microstructures on the properties of magnetic materials, (v) conduct research on geomaterials, self-healing concrete, and cosmic dust, (vi) characterize complex micro-fracture propagation in heterogeneous unconventional resources, (vii) understanding the mechanisms of self-healing concrete under harsh environmental conditions, (viii) improve the design of absorbents for the treatment of hydraulic fracturing flowback water, (ix) analyze presolar grains to identify astrophysical conditions, (x) conduct biodiversity, developmental, morphological, cytological and biomineralization research in vastly varying fields pertaining to microstructures of calcified coralline algae, fern spores, and plant organs, (xi) understand functional roles of fibroblast growth factor receptors signaling on astrocyte development, and (xii) resolve microstructures in photosynthesis proteins, and in extracellular matrix of tumor cells.

This project is jointly funded by CBET-MRI Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Red algae (Rhodophyta) are important aquatic primary producers that are one of the most anciently diverged eukaryotic phyla with fossil remains dating back to 1.2 billion years ago. An important ecological and ancient group of marine red algae, the calcifying corallines, were examined on a Scios 2 DualBeam Focused Ion Beam scanning electron microscope (FIB-SEM) to study crust-forming (CCA) members of three orders of coralline algae (Corallinales, Hapalidiales, and Sporolithales) collected from offshore Louisiana and Texas, and worldwide. Because the CCA are calcified, studying their cells and the structure of the organism as a whole is difficult and traditional light microscopy sectioning and staining techniques prevent visualization of the entire developmental process temporally and spatially that the FIB-SEM will allow. Comparative elemental analysis of calcified cell walls in species that form nodules (rhodoliths) may have important implications in assessing changes in cell wall deposition vis-à-vis anthropogenic disturbances such as ocean acidification and ocean warming.

Production of 3-dimensional views of the ultrastructure of newly-found life history stages of unicellular microalgae residing within CCA cells allowed to situate, identify and characterize such cellular inclusions. The FIB-SEM, along with the TEM, enabled to show internal ultrastructure of such inclusions. This is mandatory for their unambiguous taxonomic identification. The FIB-SEM provided new insight into linking the CCA architecture and type of calcium carbonate polymorph with microscopic stages of microalgae, helped resolve incomplete life histories, and enabled the linkage of previously unknown stages of bloom-forming microalgae residing within CCA cells with their free-living stages based on ultrastructure, a current “hot” topic of great interest to Harmful Algal Blooms (HAB) research. This project contributed significantly to enhancing expertise and developing the next generation of systematists and calcification experts working on coralline algae. Graduate and undergraduate students received in-depth training in biomineralization, developmental, morphological, cytological and biodiversity research that broadened the base of biologists who work on more general biodiversity-based questions.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2023
Modified by: Sherry L Krayesky-Self
